title: Galatians Chapter 3 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Galatians chapter 3 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Galatians Chapter 3 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Galatians Chapter 3.

questions.question: Who hath been evidently set forth crucified among the Galatians?
options: Jesus Christ
Paul
Moses
Abraham
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:1 states that Jesus Christ hath been evidently set forth, crucified among the Galatians.

questions.question: How did the Galatians receive the Spirit according to Paul's question?
options: By the works of the law
By the hearing of faith
By their own righteousness
By the law of Moses
questions.correctAnswer: By the hearing of faith
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:2 asks whether they received the Spirit by the works of the law or by the hearing of faith.

questions.question: What does Paul compare to being made perfect by the flesh after beginning in the Spirit?
options: Foolishness
Wisdom
Faith
Righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: Foolishness
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:3 calls it foolishness to begin in the Spirit and be made perfect by the flesh.

questions.question: Who is cited as believing God and having it accounted to him for righteousness?
options: Abraham
Moses
David
Noah
questions.correctAnswer: Abraham
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:6 says Abraham believed God and it was counted to him for righteousness.

questions.question: Who are considered the children of Abraham according to faith?
options: They which are of faith
They which keep the law
The circumcised only
The Jews only
questions.correctAnswer: They which are of faith
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:7 states that those who are of faith are the children of Abraham.

questions.question: What was preached before the gospel unto Abraham?
options: That God would justify the heathen through faith
That the law must be obeyed
That sacrifices are necessary
That the temple would be built
questions.correctAnswer: That God would justify the heathen through faith
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:8 says the scripture foretold that God would justify the heathen through faith and preached this to Abraham.

questions.question: According to Galatians 3:10, under what are those who rely on the works of the law?
options: The curse
Blessed
Grace
Salvation
questions.correctAnswer: The curse
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:10 states that as many as are of the works of the law are under the curse.

questions.question: What does Galatians 3:13 say Christ was made for us?
options: A curse
A king
A priest
A prophet
questions.correctAnswer: A curse
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:13 explains Christ was made a curse for us to redeem us from the curse of the law.

questions.question: What might come on the Gentiles through Jesus Christ?
options: The blessing of Abraham
The law
The curse
The covenant of Sinai
questions.correctAnswer: The blessing of Abraham
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:14 says the blessing of Abraham might come on the Gentiles through Jesus Christ.

questions.question: According to Galatians 3:20, who is God described as?
options: One
Mediator
Judge
Angel
questions.correctAnswer: One
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:20 states that God is one, not a mediator of one.

questions.question: True or False: The law was given to bring life and righteousness according to Galatians 3:21.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:21 says if the law could give life, righteousness would be by the law, but it does not.

questions.question: True or False: According to Galatians 3:26, all are children of God by faith in Christ Jesus.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:26 clearly states that ye are all children of God by faith in Christ Jesus.

questions.question: True or False: Galatians 3:25 teaches that after faith has come, we remain under the schoolmaster (law).
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:25 says that after faith has come, we are no longer under a schoolmaster.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Galatians 3:28: 'There is neither Jew nor Greek, there is neither bond nor free, there is neither male nor ______: for ye are all one in Christ Jesus.'
options: female
child
adult
servant
questions.correctAnswer: female
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:28 states that there is neither male nor female; all are one in Christ Jesus.

questions.question: What happens to those who have been baptized into Christ according to Galatians 3:27?
options: They have put on Christ
They become priests
They are justified by works
They receive the law
questions.correctAnswer: They have put on Christ
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:27 says as many as have been baptized into Christ have put on Christ.

medium.title: Galatians Chapter 3 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Galatians Chapter 3 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with doubt after beginning their walk in faith. Based on Galatians 3, what biblical truth would you share about the source of spiritual growth?
options: Spiritual growth comes by continuing in the flesh
Spiritual growth comes by faith and the Spirit, not by works
Spiritual growth is only achieved by strict law-keeping
Spiritual growth depends on human effort and wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual growth comes by faith and the Spirit, not by works
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:3 teaches that believers begin in the Spirit but are not made perfect by the flesh. Verses 2 and 5 also emphasize receiving the Spirit by hearing faith, not by works of the law.

questions.question: How does Galatians 3 teach us about the foundation of righteousness in the Christian life?
options: Righteousness is achieved through perfect law-keeping
Righteousness is accounted to those who believe God
Righteousness comes by human effort and sacrifice
Righteousness depends on social status and heritage
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness is accounted to those who believe God
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:6 shows Abraham was accounted righteous because he believed God. Verses 11 and 22 affirm that the just live by faith and that righteousness comes through faith in Jesus Christ.

questions.question: What encouragement does Galatians 3 offer to believers facing trials in their faith journey?
options: Their suffering is meaningless and wasted
They should return to law-keeping for approval
Their suffering is not in vain if they continue in faith
They must rely on their own strength to overcome
questions.correctAnswer: Their suffering is not in vain if they continue in faith
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:4 asks if their many sufferings have been in vain, implying endurance in faith is meaningful. Verses 2 and 5 stress the importance of faith rather than works.

questions.question: A new believer wonders how the promise of blessing relates to faith. Based on Galatians 3, what biblical principle would you share?
options: Blessings come only through observing the law
Blessings come to those who are of faith like Abraham
Blessings are reserved only for the Jewish people
Blessings depend on personal merit and good deeds
questions.correctAnswer: Blessings come to those who are of faith like Abraham
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:7 and 3:9 teach that those who have faith are children of Abraham and blessed with him. Verse 8 explains the gospel was preached to Abraham as a promise to all nations.

questions.question: How does Galatians 3 guide us in understanding the role of the law in the life of a believer?
options: The law is the ultimate means to righteousness and life
The law was added because of transgressions until Christ came
The law contradicts the promises of God and should be rejected
The law is no longer relevant in any way for believers
questions.correctAnswer: The law was added because of transgressions until Christ came
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:19 explains the law was added because of transgressions until the promised seed (Christ) came. Verses 21 and 23 clarify the law was a schoolmaster leading to Christ.

questions.question: According to Galatians 3, what is the proper basis for receiving the Spirit and experiencing miracles?
options: By observing all commands of the law
By hearing and believing through faith
By performing religious rituals perfectly
By lineage and family heritage
questions.correctAnswer: By hearing and believing through faith
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:5 questions whether the Spirit and miracles come by works of the law or by faith hearing, affirming it is through faith that these are received.

questions.question: A believer is confused about justification. What does Galatians 3 say about justification by the law versus by faith?
options: Justification is only possible through law-keeping
No one is justified by the law; the just live by faith
Justification comes equally from law and faith
Justification depends on personal achievements
questions.correctAnswer: No one is justified by the law; the just live by faith
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:11 states it is evident no one is justified by law, because 'the just shall live by faith.' Verses 21 and 22 confirm that righteousness and promise come through faith, not law.

questions.question: What does Galatians 3 teach about the curse of the law and Christ's redeeming work?
options: Christ is cursed because He broke the law
Christ redeemed us from the curse by becoming a curse for us
The curse of the law still applies to believers
The law has no curse associated with it
questions.correctAnswer: Christ redeemed us from the curse by becoming a curse for us
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:13 teaches Christ redeemed us from the law's curse by becoming a curse for us, fulfilling 'Cursed is every one that hangeth on a tree.' This frees believers from the curse.

questions.question: How does Galatians 3 instruct us to view unity and equality among believers?
options: Differences of race and status remain important in Christ
All believers are one in Christ Jesus, regardless of background
Only Jews are truly part of God's family
Gender and social distinctions determine standing with God
questions.correctAnswer: All believers are one in Christ Jesus, regardless of background
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:28 states there is neither Jew nor Greek, bond nor free, male nor female, for all are one in Christ Jesus, emphasizing equality and unity in the body of Christ.

questions.question: A believer asks about the inheritance of God's promises. According to Galatians 3, how is the inheritance received?
options: Through adherence to the law
Through faith and being Christ's seed
Through being physically descended from Abraham
Through personal good works
questions.correctAnswer: Through faith and being Christ's seed
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:29 explains if you belong to Christ, you are Abraham's seed and heirs according to the promise, stressing inheritance comes by faith, not law or physical descent.

questions.question: How does Galatians 3 describe our relationship with God after coming to faith in Christ?
options: We remain under the law as a schoolmaster
We are children of God by faith in Christ Jesus
We need to earn God's favor by works
We are separated by social and ethnic distinctions
questions.correctAnswer: We are children of God by faith in Christ Jesus
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:26 declares all believers are children of God through faith in Christ Jesus, emphasizing the new identity given by faith rather than law or works.

questions.question: True or False: Galatians 3 teaches that the law was able to give life and make people righteous before God.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:21 clarifies that if a law had been given that could give life, righteousness would have come by the law. Since righteousness comes by faith, the law does not give life.

questions.question: True or False: According to Galatians 3, the promise given to Abraham was made to many seeds as a collective group.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:16 specifies that the promise was made to Abraham's seed, singular, referring to Christ, not to many seeds, highlighting the Christ-centered nature of the promise.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "But after that faith is come, we are no longer under a _____."
options: schoolmaster
curse
law
promise
questions.correctAnswer: schoolmaster
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:25 states that once faith has come, believers are no longer under a schoolmaster, indicating the law's role as a tutor before faith was fulfilled in Christ.

questions.question: How does Galatians 3 guide believers in understanding the permanence of God's covenant compared to the law?
options: The law can annul the covenant and promises
The covenant confirmed by God cannot be annulled by the law
The law and covenant are equal and interchangeable
The covenant depends on human mediation to remain valid
questions.correctAnswer: The covenant confirmed by God cannot be annulled by the law
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:17 teaches that the covenant confirmed by God before the law was given cannot be annulled by the law, preserving the promise made to Abraham.

hard.title: Galatians Chapter 3 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Galatians Chapter 3.

questions.question: According to Galatians 3:6, whose faith is used as an example of being 'accounted to him for righteousness'?
options: Abraham
Moses
David
Isaiah
questions.correctAnswer: Abraham
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:6 states that Abraham believed God and it was counted to him as righteousness, highlighting the foundational example of faith.

questions.question: Galatians 3:8 mentions a prophecy made to Abraham about the blessing of all nations. What does this prophecy signify in the context of God's plan?
options: God would justify the Gentiles through faith
The law would be given to all nations
The temple would be built in Jerusalem
The Israelites would be freed from Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: God would justify the Gentiles through faith
questions.explanation: The scripture foresaw that God would justify the Gentiles (heathen) through faith, which was preached to Abraham as a gospel promise in Galatians 3:8.

questions.question: What does Paul mean in Galatians 3:10 when he says 'Cursed is every one that continueth not in all things which are written in the book of the law to do them'?
options: The law demands perfect obedience to avoid the curse
Only partial obedience is required
Faith can override the law's curse
The curse applies only to Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: The law demands perfect obedience to avoid the curse
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:10 emphasizes that those relying on the law are under a curse unless they perfectly obey everything written, underscoring the impossibility of justification by law.

questions.question: Galatians 3:11 quotes 'The just shall live by faith.' This phrase is a direct allusion to which Old Testament book?
options: Habakkuk
Isaiah
Jeremiah
Psalms
questions.correctAnswer: Habakkuk
questions.explanation: The phrase 'The just shall live by faith' in Galatians 3:11 quotes Habakkuk 2:4, linking justification by faith to Old Testament prophecy.

questions.question: In Galatians 3:13, why is Christ described as 'being made a curse for us'?
options: Because He died on a tree, fulfilling the curse of the law
Because He was rejected by the Jews
Because He was a prophet cursed by God
Because He followed the law perfectly
questions.correctAnswer: Because He died on a tree, fulfilling the curse of the law
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:13 explains that Christ redeemed us from the curse by being made a curse through crucifixion ('hanged on a tree'), fulfilling the law’s penalty.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'In thee shall all nations be blessed' in Galatians 3:8 in relation to the Abrahamic covenant?
options: It foreshadows the inclusion of Gentiles into God's promises
It limits blessings to the Jewish people alone
It refers only to physical descendants of Abraham
It pertains to the land covenant exclusively
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows the inclusion of Gentiles into God's promises
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:8 shows the gospel was preached to Abraham foreseeing justification of Gentiles, highlighting the universal scope of the Abrahamic blessing.

questions.question: Galatians 3:15-17 discusses the covenant made with Abraham. What point does Paul make about the relationship between the law and this covenant?
options: The law, given 430 years later, cannot annul the covenant made with Abraham
The law supersedes the covenant entirely
The covenant was dependent on the law for fulfillment
The covenant was conditional on Israel's obedience to the law
questions.correctAnswer: The law, given 430 years later, cannot annul the covenant made with Abraham
questions.explanation: Paul explains that the covenant confirmed before God in Christ predates and cannot be nullified by the law that came 430 years later (Galatians 3:15-17).

questions.question: In Galatians 3:19, what is the stated purpose of the law according to Paul?
options: It was added because of transgressions until the promised seed came
It was given to replace the covenant with Abraham
It was designed to give eternal life
It was intended to be the sole means of righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: It was added because of transgressions until the promised seed came
questions.explanation: Paul explains in Galatians 3:19 that the law was added due to transgressions and served as a temporary measure until the coming of the promised seed (Christ).

questions.question: Galatians 3:24 describes the law as a 'schoolmaster' or 'tutor.' What is the role of this 'schoolmaster' according to the verse?
options: To bring us unto Christ so we might be justified by faith
To give us eternal life through obedience
To replace the covenant of promise
To lead the Gentiles in righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: To bring us unto Christ so we might be justified by faith
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:24 states that the law was a schoolmaster to guide us to Christ, enabling justification by faith rather than law.

questions.question: Galatians 3:26 states, 'For ye are all the children of God by faith in Christ Jesus.' This statement emphasizes which theological concept?
options: Justification and adoption as children of God through faith
Inheritance based on works of the law
Exclusive rights of Jewish believers
Separation of Jews and Gentiles in salvation
questions.correctAnswer: Justification and adoption as children of God through faith
questions.explanation: This verse highlights that all believers become God's children through faith in Christ, underscoring justification and spiritual adoption (Galatians 3:26).

questions.question: Galatians 3:28 declares there is neither Jew nor Greek, bond nor free, male nor female. What literary device is Paul using here to convey unity in Christ?
options: Triadic parallelism
Chiasm
Simile
Allegory
questions.correctAnswer: Triadic parallelism
questions.explanation: Paul uses triadic parallelism by listing three paired categories (ethnic, social, gender) to emphasize equality and unity in Christ (Galatians 3:28).

questions.question: True or False: According to Galatians 3:22, Scripture concludes all under sin to make the promise by faith available to believers.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:22 teaches that Scripture confines all under sin so that the promise by faith in Jesus Christ may be granted to believers, confirming the truth of the statement.

questions.question: Galatians 3:20 states, 'Now a mediator is not a mediator of one, but God is one.' What is the significance of this statement in Paul's argument?
options: It emphasizes God's unity and that the law's mediation differs from God's singularity
It means there are many mediators equal to God
It suggests the law is a mediator alongside God
It denies the existence of any mediator
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes God's unity and that the law's mediation differs from God's singularity
questions.explanation: Paul contrasts the law, which was mediated, with God's oneness, underscoring God’s unique authority and the temporary role of the law’s mediator (Galatians 3:20).

questions.question: Which theme in Galatians 3:27-29 highlights the breaking down of social and ethnic barriers through faith in Christ?
options: Unity and equality of believers in Christ
Separation of Jews and Gentiles
Exclusive law observance for salvation
The superiority of the law over faith
questions.correctAnswer: Unity and equality of believers in Christ
questions.explanation: These verses emphasize that baptism into Christ unites all believers as Abraham’s seed and heirs, eliminating distinctions of race, status, or gender (Galatians 3:27-29).

questions.question: Galatians 3:2 and 3:5 both pose questions about receiving the Spirit. What contrast is Paul making in these verses?
options: Receiving the Spirit by works of the law versus by hearing of faith
Receiving the Spirit only by circumcision
Receiving the Spirit through sacrifices
Receiving the Spirit by genealogical descent
questions.correctAnswer: Receiving the Spirit by works of the law versus by hearing of faith
questions.explanation: Paul contrasts receiving the Spirit through law-works with receiving Him through faith hearing, emphasizing faith as the means of reception (Galatians 3:2,5).

theological.title: Galatians Chapter 3 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Galatians Chapter 3 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Galatians 3, by what means did Abraham receive righteousness?
options: By works of the law
By his own merit
By believing God
By offering sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: By believing God
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:6 states that Abraham believed God and it was accounted to him for righteousness. This aligns with Romans 4:3, Genesis 15:6, Hebrews 11:8-12, and James 2:23, which affirm that faith, not works, is the basis of justification.

questions.question: What does Galatians 3 say about those who rely on works of the law?
options: They are under the curse
They are blessed by God
They receive the Spirit
They are justified by faith
questions.correctAnswer: They are under the curse
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:10 explains that those who rely on works of the law are under a curse because they do not continue in all things written in the law. This is consistent with Deuteronomy 27:26, James 2:10, Romans 3:20, and Galatians 3:11, which teach that the law demands perfect obedience, and failure results in curse or condemnation.

questions.question: What role did the law serve according to Galatians 3:19?
options: A permanent covenant between God and man
A schoolmaster to bring us unto Christ
Added because of transgressions until the promised seed came
The means to eternal life
questions.correctAnswer: Added because of transgressions until the promised seed came
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:19 states the law was added because of transgressions until the seed to whom the promise was made came. This matches Exodus 20 (giving of the law), Hebrews 10:1 (law as shadow), and Romans 5:20 (law increased transgression), showing the law's temporary and preparatory function.

questions.question: How does Galatians 3 describe the blessing of Abraham in relation to the Gentiles?
options: The blessing is exclusive to Jews only
The blessing comes through the law
The blessing comes on the Gentiles through Jesus Christ
The blessing is received by works
questions.correctAnswer: The blessing comes on the Gentiles through Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:14 explains that the blessing of Abraham might come on the Gentiles through Jesus Christ so they may receive the promise of the Spirit through faith. This is consistent with Genesis 12:3, Isaiah 42:6, Acts 10:34-35, and Romans 15:8-12, revealing God's plan of salvation for all nations through Christ.

questions.question: What is the relationship between faith and the law according to Galatians 3:11-12?
options: The law is of faith and justifies by works
No one is justified by the law; the just live by faith
The law and faith both justify equally
Faith is unnecessary if the law is obeyed
questions.correctAnswer: No one is justified by the law; the just live by faith
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:11-12 clarifies that justification is not by the law but by faith, quoting Habakkuk 2:4 that 'the just shall live by faith.' Romans 1:17, Hebrews 10:38, and Revelation 14:12 also affirm that faith is the principle of righteous living apart from works of the law.

questions.question: How does Galatians 3:13 describe Christ's redemptive work in relation to the law's curse?
options: Christ upheld the law's curse on sinners
Christ redeemed us by fulfilling the law perfectly
Christ redeemed us from the curse by becoming a curse for us
Christ abolished the law entirely
questions.correctAnswer: Christ redeemed us from the curse by becoming a curse for us
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:13 states Christ redeemed us from the curse of the law by being made a curse for us, citing Deuteronomy 21:23. This substitutionary atonement is echoed in Isaiah 53:4-6, 2 Corinthians 5:21, and Romans 8:3, emphasizing Christ's vicarious sacrifice to free believers from condemnation.

questions.question: What does Galatians 3:16 reveal about the promises made to Abraham and his seed?
options: The promises were made to many seeds, the nation of Israel
The promises were made to Abraham and all his descendants equally
The promises were made to one seed, Christ
The promises were conditional on keeping the law
questions.correctAnswer: The promises were made to one seed, Christ
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:16 interprets the promise to Abraham's seed as singular, referring to Christ. This messianic fulfillment corresponds with Genesis 22:18, Isaiah 9:6, Luke 3:34, and Hebrews 2:16, affirming Christ as the ultimate fulfillment of God's covenant promises.

questions.question: According to Galatians 3:24, what purpose did the law serve before faith came?
options: To provide eternal life by obedience
To be an end in itself
To be a schoolmaster to bring us unto Christ
To replace faith
questions.correctAnswer: To be a schoolmaster to bring us unto Christ
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:24 describes the law as a schoolmaster to lead us to Christ so we might be justified by faith. This pedagogy is supported by Romans 3:20, Hebrews 7:19, 10:1, and Psalm 19:7, indicating the law's role in revealing sin and pointing to the need for Christ.

questions.question: What is the status of believers after faith has come, according to Galatians 3:25?
options: They remain under the law
They are no longer under a schoolmaster
They must keep the law perfectly
They lose their status as children of God
questions.correctAnswer: They are no longer under a schoolmaster
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:25 states that after faith has come, believers are no longer under a schoolmaster (the law). This reflects the new covenant reality in Jeremiah 31:31-34, Hebrews 8:6-13, Romans 7:6, and 2 Corinthians 3:6 where faith in Christ supersedes the law's custodial role.

questions.question: What does Galatians 3:28 teach about the unity of believers in Christ?
options: There is division based on ethnicity and gender
Only Jews are children of God
There is neither Jew nor Greek, bond nor free, male nor female; all are one in Christ Jesus
Believers must maintain social distinctions
questions.correctAnswer: There is neither Jew nor Greek, bond nor free, male nor female; all are one in Christ Jesus
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:28 emphasizes the complete spiritual unity of all believers in Christ regardless of ethnicity, social status, or gender. This is consistent with Colossians 3:11, Ephesians 2:14-16, Acts 10:34-35, and 1 Corinthians 12:13, underscoring the inclusive nature of the gospel.

questions.question: According to Galatians 3:22, why has Scripture concluded all under sin?
options: So that the law would be abolished
So that the promise by faith in Jesus Christ might be given to those who believe
Because faith is unnecessary
To prove that works justify
questions.correctAnswer: So that the promise by faith in Jesus Christ might be given to those who believe
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:22 teaches that Scripture has confined all under sin to show that salvation comes by faith in Jesus Christ. This is supported by Romans 3:9-20, Psalm 14:3, Isaiah 53:6, and 1 John 1:8, affirming universal sinfulness and the necessity of faith for righteousness.

questions.question: What does Galatians 3:26 say about how one becomes a child of God?
options: By keeping the law perfectly
By faith in Christ Jesus
By ethnic descent from Abraham
By works of righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: By faith in Christ Jesus
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:26 states that all are children of God through faith in Christ Jesus. This spiritual adoption is affirmed in John 1:12, Romans 8:14-17, Ephesians 1:5, and 1 John 3:1, highlighting faith as the means to divine sonship.

questions.question: How does Galatians 3:27 describe the effect of baptism into Christ?
options: It washes away the law
It is a work that earns salvation
Those baptized have put on Christ
It is optional for believers
questions.correctAnswer: Those baptized have put on Christ
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:27 teaches that all baptized into Christ have put on Christ, symbolizing union with Him. This is consistent with Romans 6:3-5, Colossians 2:12, Titus 3:5, and 1 Corinthians 12:13, indicating baptism as an outward sign of inward spiritual reality.

questions.question: What does Galatians 3:15 teach about the permanence of God's covenant promises?
options: They can be annulled or added to by men
They are permanent and cannot be annulled once confirmed
They depend on human effort to maintain
They are conditional on the law
questions.correctAnswer: They are permanent and cannot be annulled once confirmed
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:15 states that even a human covenant, once confirmed, cannot be annulled or added to. This principle underscores the unchanging nature of God's promises, as seen in Hebrews 6:17-18, 2 Corinthians 1:20, Psalm 89:34, and Numbers 23:19.

questions.question: According to Galatians 3:20, what is said about the nature of a mediator?
options: A mediator represents only one party
God is one and not a mediator
A mediator is not of one but represents both parties
There is no need for a mediator
questions.correctAnswer: God is one and not a mediator
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:20 indicates that a mediator is not of one, but God is one, highlighting God's unity and the unique role of Christ as mediator. This is consistent with 1 Timothy 2:5, Exodus 20:19, Hebrews 9:15, and Deuteronomy 5:5, emphasizing God's singular authority and Christ's mediatorial role.
